Let's consider a complex function \\(z(t) = e^{i \\omega t}\\) applied as a transformation on a time-dependent signal \\(x(t)\\), producing a new signal \\(y(t) = z(t) x(t)\\). Where \\(\\omega\\) is a constant representing angular frequency. This scenario explores the relation and transformation effect with and without interventions such as changing the frequency or applying a damping factor.

By directly evolving the transformed signal \\(y(t) = z(t) x(t)\\) from time 0 to T without any additional changes, will \\(y(T)\\) be identical to merely scaling \\(x(T)\\) with \\(e^{i \\omega T}\\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\(z(t) = e^{i \\omega t}\\) is consistently applied through the duration, equivalent to scaling \\(x(t)\\) by \\(e^{i \\omega t}\\) at each point in time. Therefore, at time T, \\(y(T)\\) is just \\(x(T)\\) scaled by \\(e^{i \\omega T}\\), as no additional transformations interfere.
